awd_titl_txt: Escaping Poverty: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy and Social Protection
awd_abstract_narration:
Mental disorders account for 13% of diseases in middle and low-income countries and often appear together with poverty. The proposed research project (Escaping Poverty Project (EP)) will study the link between mental health and efforts to improve economic productivity for those in extreme poverty through a 7,330 household multi-arm field experimental methods. It also seeks to study the barriers to escaping poverty through and anti-poverty asset transfer and training program.  EP examines the link between mental disorders and poverty from two perspectives. First, it investigates the interaction between improvements in mental health and the ability of households to take advantage of new opportunities; and second, it measures the effect of sustained coaching on the return to the asset grant. The results of this research project have the potential to influence social protection policies for those in extreme poverty.   The results of this study will offer guidance on the importance of mental health for the success of a strictly "economic" intervention. The results will provide important inputs into the US's efforts to reduce poverty of its citizens and around the world.  The results will also help improve the effectiveness of US's aid policies.  

The EP Project's end-line survey funded through this grant will measure consumption, income, wealth, depression, and reported mental wellbeing 24 months after asset transfer and training. The main arms in the study are as follows: a 12-week cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) program; the same CBT program followed by a multi-faceted anti-poverty asset transfer and training program; the multi-faceted program without CBT; a one-time cash transfer equivalent to the cost of the asset and training in the multi-faceted treatment arms; and a control group. Analysis will focus on average impacts of each treatment arm, as well as focus on heterogeneous impacts on specific subgroups such as those with preexisting depression and quantiles in the distribution of key outcomes. In addition to the benefits to practitioners, the study will offer knowledge about psychological barriers to investment that could perpetuate poverty traps.  The results of this research project will also provide important inputs into US's aid policies around the world.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Introduction

The Escaping Poverty (EP) project aims at addressing two challenges faced in developing nations: low incomes and poor mental health. Poverty can cause stress and in turn increase the incidence of depression, while mental health issues may inhibit individuals? ability to work productively. There is limited evidence of the interaction between mental health and economic interventions, and EP?s goal is to understand whether improved mental health allows individuals to benefit more from an economic intervention.

Project Design  

The EP project builds on the results of previous studies evaluating graduation programs, which are multifaceted interventions in which participants receive a productive asset, for example livestock, and training to manage this asset. To minimize the risk of liquidating the assets, they receive regular cash transfers. They also are given health insurance, access to a savings account, and coaching visits from an NGO field agent for two years. These multifaceted interventions have been found to improve individuals? economic conditions, with overall benefits outweighing costs. The study also tests different versions of the graduation program in Ghana, including more inexpensive and scalable versions. Prior to being selected to receive the graduation package, participants in EP were randomly selected to receive 12 weeks of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). The study has four main groups: CBT only, Graduation only, CBT and Graduation, and a control group, allowing us to test the effects of CBT and Graduation programs separately, and their interaction. In addition to these treatment arms, some households received a one-time cash transfer, equivalent to the value of the asset transfer and the consumption support given to the graduation program households.

Data Collection

The project was the result of the collaboration between Innovations for Poverty Action (IPA) and Heifer International. The project was implemented in four regions, the Upper East and Northern regions, hereafter the Northern Belt, and the Ashanti and Brong Ahafo regions, the Middle Belt. In 2016, IPA ran a baseline survey that included 7,793 households. In 2020 and 2021, the endline survey was administered to 6,830 households. The timing of the endline surveys allows us also to analyze how the coronavirus pandemic impacted the Middle Belt participants, compared to the Northern Belt participants for whom the data was collected prior to COVID-19.

The following are preliminary findings; in particular, we analyze the effect of receiving CBT only, Graduation only, CBT & Graduation, or Cash only, compared to not receiving any intervention. We present results separated by belt, to consider potential heterogeneous effects due to the timing of the endline surveys.

Results

The main outcomes of interest are weekly consumption per capita, total wealth, and total weekly income. Weekly consumption per capita consists of productive expenditures, food and non-food consumption, event and non-event spending minus the value of crop stock lost and crop expenditures.

Wealth consists of total value of livestock owned, durable and productive assets, and household savings. Total weekly income consists of total payments for livestock, land, paid work, and total value of business profits.

We find that treatment groups including CBT have on average 1.13 cedis higher per capita consumption than control. Treatment groups with any cash or any graduation experience an increase in wealth by 11.7% and 16.3% compared to control, respectively. Compared to control, treatment groups with cash, CBT, or graduation have income decrease by 13.30, 5.89, and 6.37 cedis, respectively.

To understand the income drops in the treatment groups, we parse the results by belt. In the Northern Belt, treatment groups with cash, CBT, or graduation have insignificant positive estimates compared to control. However, in the Middle Belt, these treatment groups, on average, have an income decrease of 24.84, 10.86, and 11.45, respectively. The differences in results between the two belts could potentially be attributed to the timing of the surveys. The Northern Belt completed endline data collection prior to COVID-19 while the Middle Belt completed its data collection during the pandemic, during which lockdowns in some areas resulted in disruptions for marketplace activities.

By belt, we can also separate the impacts on consumption per capita and wealth. In the Northern Belt, treatment groups with any graduation had a higher weekly consumption per capita of 1.00 cedi or 5.93%, as well as a wealth increase of 1.46% compared to control. For treatment groups with any cash, wealth increases by 1.33% compared to control. In the Middle Belt, treatment groups with any CBT experience a 1.44 cedi or 4.83% increase while groups with any graduation see a 1.62 cedi decrease compared to control in consumption per capita.

Conclusion

Following these preliminary results, we plan to do a more detailed analysis comparing the sub-components of the graduation program on a number of outcomes such as consumption, wealth, income, mental health index, and women's empowerment.
